'''Damn Small Linux''' or '''DSL''' is a [[Free software|free]] [[Linux distribution]] for the [[x86 architecture|X86]] family of [[personal computer]]s. It was designed to run [[Graphical user interface|graphical applications]] on older PC [[Computer hardware|hardware]] -- for example, machines with [[Intel 80486|486]]/early [[Pentium]] [[Microprocessor|processors]] and very little [[Random access memory|memory]]. DSL is a '''[[Live CD]]''' with a size of 50 [[Megabyte|MB]]. What originally started as an experiment to see how much software could fit in 50 MB eventually became a full-fledged [[Linux]] distribution. It can be installed on storage media with small capacities, like [[bootable business card]]s, [[USB flash drive]]s, various [[memory card]]s, and [[Zip drive]]s.
'''Damn Small Linux''' or '''DSL''' is a [[Free software|free]] [[Linux distribution]] for the [[x86 architecture|X86]] family of [[personal computer]]s. It was designed to run [[Graphical user interface|graphical applications]] on older PC [[Computer hardware|hardware]] -- for example, machines with [[Intel 80486|486]]/early [[Pentium]] [[Microprocessor|processors]] and very little [[Random access memory|memory]]. DSL is a '''[[Live CD]]''' with a size of 50 [[Megabyte|MB]]. What originally started as an experiment to see how much software could fit in 50 MB eventually became a full-fledged [[Linux]] distribution. It can be installed on storage media with small capacities, like [[bootable business card]]s, [[USB flash drive]]s, various [[memory card]]s, and [[Zip drive]]s.
